Discussion Topic

A parent tells you that her 2-year-old doesn't pick up his toys when he's done playing with them.

How could you respond to the parent to help her understand how the principles of imitation could be beneficial in modifying her son's behavior?

Sample Responses

  • Advise the parent to pick up her own things around the house. (Incorrect)
  • Suggest that when the parent plays with her son, to make sure she puts away the toys she played with when she's done. (Correct)
  • Turn toy cleanup into a fun game of copycats where the parent puts away one toy and then the son takes a turn putting away a similar toy. (Correct)
  • Encourage the parent to put away his toys for him when he's done with them. (Incorrect)

    • Sample Feedback

    His parent should model the behavior she would like him to perform. In this instance, since she wants him to pick up his toys when he is done with them, she should make sure she also puts away whatever toys she's no longer using when they play.

    Cleanup could even be turned into a fun game where they both help to pick up the toys. One idea could be to copy each other putting the toys away in a similar manner, such as quietly like a mouse, or quickly like a fox.
